msDesc.head: Collection of medical tracts and recipes

summary.seg: This manuscript is a compilation of remedies, healing instructions and diagrams with the common goal of healing a medieval person from illness and wounds. The text is illustrated at points with a table and diagrams – including a design for a plate to heal wounds, a Zodiac man and magical spheres – making it a significant example of design and material culture in addition to the content of the Middle English and Latin text. The Zodiac man and circular diagrams place this manuscript alongside many other examples that outline similar methodologies (for another example of a Zodiac man diagram, see Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 3303(3)), however the inclusion of a diagram for a plate to heal a wound is more unusual. The combination of prayers, charms, incantations and actions blur the lines between religion, magic, astrology and medicine, revealing insights into the relationship between the medieval physician and patient, and complexities surrounding ritual and efficacy for the medieval body and mind.

The charms in this manuscript can be easily recognised as a short section of text, often interspersed with crosses. They will look and read similar to a prayer and borrow religious language. The text of a charm is recited verbally, memorised or meditated on. The crosses within the text indicate that the shape of the cross is to be made physically at that point. The performance of charms is also connected with the transformation of an object into a talisman or amulet, imbuing it with a believed efficacy and power to heal.

The inclusion on folio 94v of a square diagram with a cross in each corner and in the centre connects this manuscript to five others known to contain a similar diagram used to heal wounds. They are:
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.51
London, British Library, Add. MS 15236
London, Wellcome Library, MS 407
San Marino (CA), Huntington Library, MS HM 64
Stockholm, Kungliga biblioteket, MS X.90 The five crosses, whilst a prompt for actions to be made and words to be said, also link the design and function to the cult of the five wounds. The design provides a template for the creation of a lamina, to be made with a more durable material such as lead and intended to be placed on the body for medical purposes. The text alongside the lamina instructs the user to make a plate to place on a wound. Both the making and then its medical use includes prayers to be said out loud and actions to be made, making this charm and its design an example of ritual performance used in medicine. The text instructs the reader to say the Pater Noster, the Lord’s prayer, when making any cross on the plate and when washing the wound. This is material evidence that ritual performance was thought to possess a transformative power, and was used to turn an object into a talisman or amulet. This manuscript can be studied as an example of sensory experience through its material code for the physical mimicry, performative reading, gesture and touching involved in performing this charm.

Both the text and the diagram have been censored by cross hatching lines of ink and watery brush marks. This highlights the fluidity of medieval magic and what was considered to be natural or demonic magic and acceptable or illicit. It suggests that such practices were acceptable at the time when they were copied, but that this changed at some later point. However, the legibility of the text, in spite of these deletions, implies that its practice may have continued.

In addition to its medical and performative interest, this manuscript contains plenty of physical evidence to be looked at through the lens of material culture and codicology. Trimmed folios, holes, books within books, ink changes and stitches hold clues to the life of this object. An ownership inscription, crossings out, workings out, names and signatures speak of a well-used and studied book. Delicate manicules, and a zodiac man with a great head of hair and delicate knees and ankles, stand in contrast to the rough workings-out of protective magic circles, and together represent the lasting signatures of the people who made and used this manuscript.

supportDesc.support: Two separate parts consisting of booklets of paper leaves.

foliation.p: Written in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf. Gaps in the sequence owing to the loss or partial loss of leaves. Folio 116 largely torn out. Folios 143-144 bound out of sequence.
foliation.note: ff. [19] and [134a] are unfoliated paper stubs of excised leaves featuring remains of text.
f. [v] is a sheet of paper that has been folded in half, creating two leaves that are attached to one another at the top.

Folio numbers 19, 106-109, 130, and 131 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume. Stubs after f. 18 and f. 134 have been assigned numbers for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record. These numbers are placed between square brackets to indicate that they have been supplied.

collation.p: The manuscript comprises several booklets of paper bound together, however the irregular nature of these gatherings and the tightness of the current binding mean that it is not presently possible to determine their structure.

binding.p: A 19th- or early 20th-century pasteboard binding with light brown paper on the covers.
Binding height: 230 mm; width: 155 mm; depth: 35 mm.

provenance.p: Robert Steel (fl. 17th century) Steele, Robert, 17th century : his name inscribed on f. 4r. Perhaps the Robert Steele of Harpham, Yorkshire (b. c. 1623, d. 1688): admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1640, and later headmaster of Beverley School 1645-47 and Hull School 1647-50, Vicar of Scarborough c. 1650-60, Rector of Catwick and later Brandesburton 1661-68 (see Venn, Alumni Cantabrigienses).
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 163 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : without the usual donation bookplate that was engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 and can be found on many of the inside covers of Moore's manuscripts.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) , The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.15, ff. 1-100

msItem.title: Herbal (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 1r Popie white popye
msItem.explicit: 6r Erbe Christofer
msItem.note: Part of a herbal, alphabetically arranged ('P'-'Y'); f. 6v is headed 'Y' but has no entries.
Contains an addition in an early 16th-century hand: 'ys good for aman or a woman þat is in a ffransy'.

msItem.title: Medical recipe and dietary advice
msItem.incipit: 1v Memorandum ye must take of this powder euerey mornyng fastyng fyrst or ye ete or drynke as myche at a tyme as wyll fyll a wall nutt shell
msItem.explicit: 1v And beware of mustye brede for any thynge etcaetera
msItem.note: Probably added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Astrological diagram, circular
msItem.incipit: 2r Saturnus incipit mars soll venus mercurius luna
msItem.note: The astrological text is written around a circular diagram that occurs three times: two times on f. 2r and once on f. 3r. The first diagram has an apothecary recipe (?) written inside the circle; the second diagram the word 'diatesseron'; and the third diagram does not contain text.
Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Prognostics for bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 4v Isti sunt dies in quibus expedit minuere sanguinem propter diversarum infirmitatum evitacionem
msItem.explicit: 5r Virtus, Ecclesia, Clerus, Demon, Simonia, Cessat, Calcatur, Errat, Regnat, Dominatur
msItem.note: Perhaps added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat plague
msItem.rubric: 5v A souereynge drynke for the cyr of the pestylence
msItem.incipit: 5v Take an herbe callyd pympernell and marygold leve and bete theym to joysse and drynke theym together in stale ale fastyng wiþ an emptye stomacke
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Perhaps added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat canker
msItem.incipit: 5v Mell rosarum for the canker
msItem.note: Full transcription
fragment of a medical recipe perhaps added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Latin proverb
msItem.incipit: 6r Qui pingit flores / Non pingit floris odorem
msItem.note: Full transcription.
accompanied by a drawing of a flower in dark ink; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: List of perilous days
msItem.author: Pseudo-Bede (attributed)
msItem.incipit: 6r Seint bede seyis þat iij dayis ther beth of the wich none of them be necssarij be no manner of wyse to man neyþer to beste to minish [corr. from 'uunish' in Connolly (2009), p. 95] noun of his blode neyther to take no medcynes
msItem.explicit: 6v and þe fyrste daye of the kalendere of march yf ther be ony maner chylde born in þat dayis his body shall neuer rote

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 96-97

msItem.title: The properties of apples, pears, butter, and coral
msItem.incipit: 6v Appyls and peerys be nought to be hote when they be rostyd
msItem.explicit: 6v Yt is styptyke hit cuttithe awaye hyghe flesshe yt stoppethe flux of bloode and constreynythe teerys
msItem.note: Written by the same hand.

msItem.title: Collection of twenty-five medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes a recipe to make candells ('To make Candell[es] for any man ys Lorde') on f. 10r

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 96.

msItem.title: Recipe for calfsfoot jelly
msItem.rubric: 10v A Resceyt for vj dosyn Jelly
msItem.incipit: 10v Greynes - d alb
msItem.explicit: 10v and whyll it ys hoote put it in to dyshes and then lett it kele
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Mnemonic verse on the Five Senses
msItem.incipit: 11r Nos aper auditu, linx visu, simia gustu / Vultur odoratu praecellit, aranea tactu
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.
English translations written above the lines by a (?) 16th-century hand: 'A wylde boare', 'An ape', 'A grype', 'Spyde[r]'.

msItem.title: Diagram of a Zodiac Man
msItem.incipit: 11r ther be vij bones in the heade of euery man
msItem.explicit: 11r Summa of the nowmbre of all the bones in a man summa ccxlviij biside ij oþer bones that the tonge that is cisamma and os laude

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 96-97

msItem.title: Recipe for spiced bread
msItem.rubric: 11r For viij s of spyce brede
msItem.incipit: 11r ffyrste peper i lb
msItem.explicit: 11r And thys resceytte made xs worthe of brede lackes ijd byside the spyces After iij unces jd for v s and ij caakes jd of ij s and iij caakes jd of oþer ijs s
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: List of the months according to the seasons
msItem.incipit: 11v Petyrs cheyre begynnethe ver / and Urban begynnyth Somer / Symphoryan begynythe Harvest / Clement begynnythe wynter
msItem.explicit: 11v Marche apryll and maye ver june julye and august somer september october and november harvest december janyver and february wynter
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

listBibl.bibl: For further literature, see Connolly (2009), p. 97

msItem.title: Mnemonic hand diagram with a note on a weather prognostic
msItem.incipit: 11v Memorandum that the next wensdaye after the pryme with vs is the Shypmans kalender and yf it be fayre wedder then and then it is lyke so to contynew.
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added in the 16th century.
Perhaps the text refers to the same 'Shipman's Calendar' that John Walley [Waley], stationer of London, published in 1562-63.

msItem.title: Lunary
msItem.incipit: 12r The ffryste [sic] day of the mone was Adam made this day ys gode and profitabyll to all men
msItem.explicit: 14v Sanguinem minuere non est bonum

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 360

msItem.title: Collection of ten medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection includes the Longinus charm and flum Jordan charm, a charm against the tootache with a narrative about Christ healing Abraham on the Mount of Olives
For other copies of the charms, see Connolly (2009), p. 98.

msItem.title: Collection of forty-six medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection includes the Sage Leaf charm against fever and a Beronix/Beronixa charm to staunch blood ('Waronix'-'Waronixa').

listBibl.bibl: For other copies of the Sage Leaf charm and Beronix/Beronixa charm, see Connolly (2009), p. 98

msItem.title: De viribus herbarum (translation)
msItem.author: Macer
msItem.incipit: 24v Mugworte or brotheworth is clepid arthemasia for þow þat she is moder of alle other erbys or for þey þat þe moder of erbys hath ȝeuen her name diana sykirly þe wiche is clepyd in grek tunge arthemesis
msItem.explicit: 65r ambrosiana wille drye owte of þe body þat bledyth inward as moche blode as the pacient drynkys juse of thys erbe
msItem.note: Contains 16th-century notes, e.g.: 'Mugworte brotherworte or motherworte all ys one'.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 98-99

msItem.title: Collection of thirty-seven medical recipes
msItem.note: The last recipe (for 'scietica passio') ends incompletely.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 99.

msItem.title: Herbal (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 71r Absinthium est herba calida
msItem.explicit: 72v Et apposita
msItem.note: The names of herbs are organised alphabetically, but only cover the letter 'A' ('Absintihium' to 'Arnoglassa').

msItem.title: Esdras-type prognostications based on the weekday on which Christmas Day falls
msItem.rubric: 73r Loke what day crystmas day fallyth on and so take one of thys planytes fro sonday to saturday and so shall þe ȝere be
msItem.incipit: 73r Soll: Good hony deth of old women moreyne of bestes grete tempest grete parlamentys
msItem.explicit: 73r Saturnus: hony sumdelle moch syknes of women of þe feuerys and the jaundys and moch flex moch hempe and hey

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 99.

msItem.title: Spacium de terra ad celum [Verse tract on the walking distances between the earth and the heavens]
msItem.incipit: 73r Raby and moyses þe good clerkes tellyth of wonder werkes how god hym selff made planytis .7. and by twhene euery planyte ys on heuen
msItem.explicit: 73r Thus seyth Raby and moyises and beryth wytnes þat þis ys no lese

msItem.title: Explanation on and table showing how the signs of the zodiac govern different areas of the human body
msItem.rubric: 73v Thise are the xij singnes þat reynes in man or woman to be ware for blode letyng
msItem.incipit: 73v Aries ys in þe hed
msItem.explicit: 73v Pisces ouer þe fete

listBibl.bibl: For other copiess, see Connolly (2009), p. 99

msItem.title: List of illnesses that can be diagnosed from urine with remedies
msItem.rubric: 75r To knowe alle þe syrcumstaunse in the syte of waterys
msItem.incipit: 75r Kyrapos: the dropsye wynde in þe syde þe stone ache in þe hede
msItem.explicit: 77r ete this when þyne euyll comes ouer the also use diacameron and triasandaby crubicunda ryght as þe other rubicunda

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 100

msItem.title: Uroscopic overview of the four properties of urine
msItem.incipit: 77r Euery vreyne is clene sygnes of mennes blode
msItem.explicit: 77r and yf þe residence be blac / the but yf hit be expulsyd be ureyne veneuos mater hit is syngne of dethe

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 100-101

msItem.title: List of twenty colours of urine grouped by stages of digestion
msItem.incipit: 77r Ureyna rubicunda and subrubicunda and rubea and subrubia þese iiij be toknes excesse of digestion
msItem.explicit: 77v subrufa as gold and syluer medlyd rufa as pure gold thyse ij betoknyth perfite digestion

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 101

msItem.title: List of uroscopic tokens
msItem.incipit: 77v Urina citrina when the cerkylle is of þe same colowre ys preysabille
msItem.explicit: 77v uina lucid as horne hit betoken indisposissioun of þe splene and dis-

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 101-102

msItem.title: Collection of 134 medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection includes charms for childbirth [Maria peperit cristum] (f. 78r), stillbirth, the falling sickness (ff. 93r-93v), wounds [Plate of Lead charm] (ff. 94r-94v); and a recipe for 'gracia dei secundum maister dionisium de parysse' (f. 83r)

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 102, 360-361

msItem.title: List of twenty medicinal waters
msItem.rubric: 79v Thyse ben precius waterys and vertues for dyuerise euyllys
msItem.incipit: 79v-80r Water of wormwod ys good for þe stomak for þe lyuore for þe splen for wormys in þy wombe for the jaundys for dronknes and for þe seyth and for þe feuer and for many other euyllys
msItem.explicit: 80v and hit is clepyd water imperiall for all þe grete emperouris and lordes amongyste þe sarasynis usen to dryng hit

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 102-103

msItem.title: Text on gathering herbs
msItem.incipit: 85r Mougworte may be gaderyd in euery tyme of þe ȝere
msItem.explicit: 85v flowr delyse shuld be gaderyd in þe ende of ȝer and dryid in þe sunne and hit wille laste ij ȝer and be gode

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 103

msItem.title: List of seventy-six terms denoting sickness
msItem.rubric: 98v Her beth þe seknes þat are in mannys body and womanys and dryngkys
msItem.incipit: 98v Matrice þat þe chyld lith in the moderys wombe
msItem.explicit: 99v Eucacesnia

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for healing a canker and scabs
msItem.note: Added in a later 16th-century hand

msItem.title: Explanation of weights and measures for medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 99v In medcyne þou shalt take þe wheyte be whete cornys in þis wyse
msItem.explicit: 99v sextarius ys ij li and an halffe

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 103

msItem.title: Two recipes for making ink
msItem.note: The ink recipes are part of the medical recipes above. The first one is in English (entitled: 'To make gode blak yngk as ony ys in ynglond') and the second one is in Latin.

msItem.title: List of thirty-four herbs
msItem.rubric: 100v Thise are þe namys of þe erbis wherwiþ lechis men women and chyldyr þey maye saue of all here desesys wiþinne and wiþowte
msItem.incipit: 100v Burnet / Turmentyne / Crosie / Bugylle / Pygull / Sanigle / erbe robart / erbe wauter
msItem.explicit: 100v Cochemmette þat is auerice

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded inquarto.
ff. 1r-100v: Bull's head with star

collation.p: This part of the manuscript comprises several booklets of paper bound together, however the irregular nature of these gatherings and the tightness of the current binding mean that it is not presently possible to determine their structure.

supportDesc.condition: Stains from damp around the edges, but without affecting the text. The upper half of f. 10 has been cut out (with loss of text on f. 10r). The outer halves of ff. 4-5 have been cut off vertically; the upper half of f. 10 has been cut off horizontally; f. 98 and 99 have been sewn together with blue thread. A stub with remains of writing between ff. 18 and 20 has been counted in the early modern foliation.

layout.seg: Frames (occasionally) ruled in blindpoint (outer vertical line only). Single columns except for ff. 100v which has two columns. c. 30-c. 40 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Several cursive hands, mostly writing in scripts with both Anglicana and Secretary features throughout.

decoNote.p: Circular astrological diagrams in brown ink on f. 2r and f. 3r.
Diagram of a zodiac man in brown ink with yellow used for hair colour on f. 11r.
Diagram of a mnemonic hand in brown ink with red used for the cross section of the wrist on f. 11v.
Diagram of a lead plate with five crossed drawn in brown ink in the margin of f. 94v.
Large brown initials with cadels and minor decorative elements throughout (e.g. f. 65r).
Manicules in brown ink throughout the manuscript.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 15th century.
origin.p:
The manuscript's collections of recipes contain various references to London, e.g.:
f. 21v: 'provyd in london with hye and lowe'.
f. 22v: 'by provyd diuerse tymes in london'.
f. 152r: 'A medycyn for the swetyng sekenesse that was sett vp apoun pawllesgate' refers to St Paul’s Gate, which situated at the intersection of Paternoster Row and Cheapside Street, giving access to St Paul’s Cathedral’s churchyard.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.15, ff. 101-156

msItem.title: Notes on herbs
msItem.incipit: 101r Boras commestum auget luxuriam superhabundant
msItem.explicit: 101r ffemina luxuriosa bibat solseq. et betonicam distem poratum cum aceto et cessabit luxuria

msItem.title: Collection of 200 medical recipes
msItem.note: Written by different hands
Contains a crossed-out charm entitled 'Misse contra morbum Caducum' (f. 102r) and an instruction for preserving oysters (f. 112v)
Includes extracts from a text on the virtues of herbs on ff. 118r-119r.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 101-102

msItem.title: Tract on taking out writs
msItem.incipit: 126v Iff there be any man that is willing to be attournay for ony man if he will of dett or trespas in the kinges bynch or in the commyn place furst he must haue an oryginall writt out of the chauncerie
msItem.explicit: 127v item þere is an habias corpus þe fee is þere of ijs vjd item a procendo upon the same and the fee is ijs vjd

msItem.title: Lists of replevisable and irreplevisable crimes
An indulgence
msItem.incipit: 128r Auctoritate dei patris omnipotentis Apostolorum Petri et Pauli et tocius matris ecclesie ac virtute huius Bulle papalis indulgencie absoluo te ab omnibus peccatis tuis mihi confessis et de quibus velles fonfiteri [sic: confiteri] si tue occurrerent memorie ac de censuris et penis quibuscumque inte a Jure vel ab homine latus
msItem.explicit: 128r Et concedo tibi omnium pecccatorum tuorum cenurarorum sentenciarum et penarum quarumcumque plerissimum remissionem et absoluacionem in quantum Claues Ecclesie se extendunt in hac parte et Jubilei graciam Ita vt sis absolutus ante tribunal domini nostri Jhesu Christi habeas que vitam eternam et viuas in secula seculorum Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription; text crossed out and the word 'Bulle papalis' inked out; followed by a crossed-out list of popes: Paulus papa secundus regnauit - annus / Pius papa secundus regnauit - annus / Sixtus papa tertius regnauit - annus'.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 101-102

msItem.title: List of distances with seventy-six entries, charting a journey from Gravelines (near Calais) to Rome
msItem.incipit: 128v ffro grauelyn to dunkyrk - ix myle
msItem.explicit: 129r ffro turbeacane to rome xiiij myle

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 101-102

msItem.title: Text on procreation and the genital organs
msItem.incipit: 133r Almyghty god hath made that procreacon of persons male and female and membris made for the same and mervelous concupissens and inseperable dilectacion hathe annexid therto
msItem.explicit: 134r yff ye will restreyne that mater R agnus castus otherwise callid tutsaue and pety morell boyle them well in water and wiþ that wassh your prevy membris etcaetera

msItem.title: De virtute quercus (translation)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Arnoldus de Villanova
msItem.rubric: 150r The treatyse of the oke tree hys froytte and his leves
msItem.incipit: 150r Master arlnold [sic] of newtowne the excelent doctor hauyng great experyence in physyck hathe drawen a treatise of the oke by the whiche hymself and to desyn by the vertue of god the whiche gavithe medycyn everlastyng the whiche mr arnold hathe made the sentens of the sayenge of Galyen and Avycen, Arystotyll, and Albert, and other ffeythefull men
msItem.explicit: 152v and bere theym pryvely and other men knowythe yt not and byfore men they blame the leves and saye they have no vertue
msItem.finalRubric: 151v explicit the vertue of the oke

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 101-102

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. ff. 101-134 and 145-156: Flower and Hand with star

collation.p: This part of the manuscript comprises several booklets of paper bound together, however the irregular nature of these gatherings and the tightness of the current binding mean that it is not presently possible to determine their structure.

supportDesc.condition: A stub with remains of writing between 134 and 135 has not been counted in the early modern foliation. Folios 135-142 are smaller leaves (160 x 110 mm) that form a separate quire.

layout.seg: Frames (occasionally) ruled in blindpoint (outer vertical line only). Single columns except for ff. 100v which has two columns. c. 25-c. 30 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Several cursive hands, mostly writing in scripts with both Anglicana and Secretary features throughout the manuscript.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

origin.p: The collection contains two dated recipes: one recipe for curing the Sweating Sickness, entitled ffor the new agew called the new acqueynttance Ao xxxijo Regni Regis H[enrici] octaui, is dated to 1540/1 (f. 111v); another recipe, entitled A souereyn medysyn for to stoppe a laske other of man or Chylde, has the year 1520 written above it (f. 115r).

The manuscript's recipes refer to a number of patients and medical practitioners from early 16th-century London: Mastres Roppyssleys medycyn and plaster (f. 103r) may refer to the wife of Thomas Ropysley who is named a citizen and surgeon of London in his will of 1504. But the Mastres Wallwyn the Awdytours wyff who is also associated with the recipe must be must be one of the three wives of William Walwyn of Kensington, auditor for the king and the duchy of Lancaster, who made his will in 1535 Kew, The National Archives, PROB 11/27/88). She could be his first wife Alice, who had died and was buried in St Bartholomew’s Hospital in West Smithfield when William made his will; his second wife Katherine whose marriage seems to have ended with divorce; or his third wife Sibylla (Sible) who was still alive in 1535.

The collection also contains a recipe for curing toothache that is said to have been proved good by Sir John Thurston knyȝt (f. 115v). It probably refers to John Thurston, knight, goldsmith and alderman of the City of London whose will was drawn up in 1520. This identification can be confirmed from a recipe for treating pain in the limbs (f. 156v) that is said to have been proved by three men: two knights named John Thurston and Thomas Exmew, and a priest of a church dedicated to St Peter named John Chaunterell (quod probatum fuit per dominum Johannum Thurston militem et per dominum Exmew Militem et per magistrem johannum chawnterell rectorem ecclesie sancti petri). While the first is the aforementioned John Thurston, the second probably is Thomas Exmewe, another goldsmith and alderman of London (1508–29), who was Sheriff of London in 1508 and Lord Mayor of London in 1517. The priest probably is the John Chaunterell who was rector of the church of St Peter in Westcheap from 1492 until his death in 1509.

The manuscript's second part contains two recipes that are attributed to a doctor Bentley: a medycyn tawght by magister doctor Bentley doctor of physyke (f. 124r) and good Medycyn [...] gevyn by Doctor bentley (f. 124r). He probably was Thomas Bentley who became Bachelor of Medicine at the University of Oxford in 1516, and received the degree of Doctor of Medicine in 1518. He was soon chosen as physician to the Duke of Buckingham. In 1521, he was several times consulted by Henry VIII. In 1523, he was appointed Censor of the Royal College of Physicians, and its President four times between 1525 and 1530 (see C.H. Talbot and E.A. Hammond, The Medical Practitioners in Medieval England: A Biographical Register (London: Wellcome Historical Library, 1965), p. 334.

On the basis of the previous identifications, the Master Twysellton who is mentioned in a recipe (ffor the fflyxe a medycyn whiche is callyd M. Twyselltons) on f. 103v may refer to John Twisleton who was a goldsmith and alderman of the City and died in 1525.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
